RegExp Class

The RegExp class is a class for handling regular expression patterns.
Perl-compatible patterns can be specified as regular expression patterns.
It is similar to the JavaScript RegExp class, but compatibility is low.

The constructor syntax is as follows:
new RegExp(<pattern string>, <flag string=''>);
The pattern string is a regular expression pattern. Note that when writing a \ in a string literal, you must write it as \\.
The flag string is a combination of the characters g, i, and l.
g is the global search flag. When this flag is set, the match, exec, and replace methods will process all parts of the string that match the pattern.
The i flag ignores uppercase/lowercase distinctions in alphabetic characters.
The l flag is a flag to enable localized collation.


Example:
    var re = new RegExp("[a-z]+[0-9]*", "gi");
    var re = new RegExp("\\.\\.\\."); // /\.\.\./ ( to match ... )

Regular Expression Patterns

Regular expression patterns can be specified by enclosing them within / and /.
Please refer to Tokens.

compile

The compile method sets a new regular expression pattern for the regular expression object.
The arguments are the same as those specified for the RegExp class constructor.

test

The test method returns whether the string specified in the argument matches the pattern.

Syntax : test(<string>)
Returns true if it matches the pattern, false otherwise.
This method updates the values of each property of this object.

exec

The exec method performs regular expression pattern matching on the string specified in the argument and returns an array containing the matching results.

Syntax : exec(<string>)
If the pattern does not match, the number of array elements is 0.
If it matches, element 0 (the first element) contains the entire matched part, and subsequent elements contain each matched sub-part (the parts specified by ( ) in the regular expression pattern).
This method updates the values of each property of this object.

match

The match method is identical to the exec method, except that it does not update the values of this object's properties.

Syntax : match(<string>)

replace

The replace method replaces strings and returns the string after replacement.

Syntax : replace(<target string>, <replacement string>)
Performs matching against the target string, replaces the matched parts with the replacement string, and returns the string after replacement.
If a function is passed instead of a string as the replacement string, that function will be called for the replacement operation. The function takes one argument, an array object representing the matched part in the target string (refer to the exec method for details on this array). The matched part in the target string is replaced by the string returned by the function.
This method ignores the start property.

split

The split method splits a string.

Syntax : split(<target string>, <(reserved)>, <ignore empty elements=false>)
Returns an array object containing the result of splitting the string.
Please also refer to the split method of the Array Class.

matches

The matches property is a read-only property that represents an array containing each matched part.
If the pattern does not match, the number of array elements is 0.
If it matches, element 0 (the first element) contains the entire matched part, and subsequent elements contain each matched sub-part (the parts specified by ( ) in the regular expression pattern).

start

A property representing the search start position in the string. A value can also be set.

index

A read-only property representing the position of the first character of the matched part. Since 0 represents the beginning, if it is the first character of the matching target string, it will be 0.

lastIndex

A read-only property representing the position of the character following the last character of the matched part. 0 represents the beginning.

input

A read-only property representing the string being matched.

leftContext

A read-only property representing the string to the left of the matched part within the matching target string.

rightContext

A read-only property representing the string to the right of the matched part within the matching target string.

lastMatch

Represents the matched part of the target string. Same as matches[0].

lastParen

Returns the last part among the matched sub-parts. Same as matches[matches.count-1].

RegExp.last

The instance of the RegExp class on which the test or exec method was last executed.
Example : if(/pat(\d+)/.test(target)) { return RegExp.last.matches[1]; }
